'''Mona el-Shazly''' ({{lang-ar|Ù ÙÙ Ø§ÙØ´Ø§Ø°ÙÙ}}) is an [[Egypt]]ian talk show host. She is known for her talk show ''[[Al Ashira Masa'an]]'' ({{LangWithName|en|English|''10 O'Clock''}}) where she talks about news of the day and interviews Egyptian and foreign politicians, scientists, and Islamic elders.
== Early life == El-Shazly graduated from high school in the [[United Arab Emirates]] and then studied [[political science]] at the [[American University in Cairo]].
==Career== El-Shazly worked in [[Public Relations]] at the [[The Arab Contractors (Company)|Arab Contractors Company]].
She hosted several programs on the [[Saudi Arabia|Saudi]]-owned [[Arab Radio and Television Network]] Channel.
She has been at Dream 2 Channel since 2006, hosting ''Al Ashira Masa'an''. Dream TV is a popular independent Egyptian satellite channel. "By her own estimate, she is one of the highest paid hosts on Arabic satellite television," a report said.<ref name="NYT01"/> Her contract with Dream Channel is estimated between 2 to 3 million Egyptian pounds per year (appx. LE200,000/month).{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} Addressing "government pressure on journalists in Egypt[;] 'They donât understand that a presenter is not a spokesperson for the government or the regime,' she said. 'I am not a spokesman. But you always have this problem.'"<ref name="NYT01"/>
===''Al Ashira Masa'an''=== Some of the guests that have been featured on the show are:
*[[Mohamed Elbaradei]], former Director General of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) and [[Nobel Prize]] winner *[[Ahmed Zewail]], scientist and [[Nobel Prize]] winner *[[Ahmed Ezz]], Egyptian politician and business tycoon *[[Naseer Shamma]], [[Arab]] [[Iraq]]i musician and [[oud]] player *[[Gamal El-Ghitani]], author and magazine editor *[[Alaa Al Aswany]], author and founder of the political movement [[Kefaya]] *[[Yusuf Al-Qaradawi]], Muslim scholar and head of the International Union for Muslim Scholars *[[Amr Khaled]], Islamic activist and founder of life makers and right start foundation [http://www.rightstart.org.uk] *[[Omar Khairat]], musician *[[Talaat Sadat]], former Egyptian politician and current [[political prisoner]]. *[[Ayman Nour]], politician; chairman of the [[Tomorrow Party|El Ghad]] party. *[[George W. Bush]], [[United States of America|U.S.]] president; during the ten-minute interview on May 13, 2008, they discussed Egyptian-American relations and the issues of [[Palestine]] and [[Iran]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ikhwanweb.com/article.php?id=17120|title= Mona al Shazly interview with Dubya |date= May 17, 2008|work= www.ikhwanweb.com|accessdate= March 14, 2010}}</ref> *[[Wael Ghonim]], Google marketing executive and one of the organizers of the [[2011 Egyptian protests|Jan25 movement]] in early 2011; an emotional interview after he had just been released from an 11-day secret detention; the dead were mourned and the [[Wael Ghonim#2011 Egyptian protest involvement|movement given new life]] by the broadcast, which "undercut two weeks of relentless state propaganda" according to a report<ref name="NYT01">Fahim, Kareem and Mana El-Naggar; Liam Stack and Ed Ou contributed reporting, [http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/09/world/middleeast/09ghonim.html?_r=1&scp=1&sq=Mona%20El-Nagger&st=cse "Emotions of a Reluctant Hero Galvanize Protesters"], ''The New York Times'', February 8, 2011 (February 9, 2011 p.
